required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Fast Bar on Physiological Fasting
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Single-blinded, Controlled, Parallel-arm Study to Evaluate the Effect of Fast Bar(TM) on Physiological Fasting Condition

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates how Fast Bar(TM), a specially formulated energy bar, affects the physiological condition in participants after an overnight fasting. Participants will fast for 19 hours (Fast Group), consume a breakfast Bar (Breakfast Group) or a Fast Bar(TM) (Fast Bar Group) after an approximately 15-hour overnight fasting. Participants will be assessed for physiological parameters associated with fasting.

detailed_description.textblock:
Interest in fasting-based programs (i.e. intermittent fasting) for improvement of health and longevity continues to grow. While benefits of intermittent fasting have been convincingly demonstrated in rodent models, the more limited data in humans is less clear.
The short-term fasting (e.g. 12 to 48 hours in duration) utilized in many intermittent fasting programs are considered safe, but some individuals may find them subjectively difficult. As such, the question of whether the benefits of fasting can be obtained while small amounts of food are consumed is of substantial interest.
One commercially available product that is designed to be consumed during periods of intermittent fasting is the Fast Bar™,which stems out of the well-researched fasting-mimicking diet to assist prolonged fasting. The unique formulation of the Fast Bar™ is hypothesized to minimize deviations in metabolic biomarkers associated with a fasting state. This may allow for extension of a fasting period through reduced subjective difficulty of fasting.The objective of this study is to evaluate the metabolic and subjective effects of consuming a novel food product (Fast Bar™) after a short period of fasting.

study_design_info.masking_description: For comparison between the placebo breakfast bar and the Fast Bar groups, the participants are masked.

primary_outcome.time_frame: BHB Area Under the Curve between 0 to 4 hours after consuming the study foods
primary_outcome.description: Blood ketone (ß-hydroxybutyrate, BHB) area under the curve (AUC) will be measured with a Abbott Precision Xtra Blood Glucose and Ketone Monitoring Meter Kit on 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours after consuming the study foods.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Glucose Area Under the Curve between 0 to 4 hours after consuming the study foods
primary_outcome.description: Blood glucose area under the curve (AUC) will be measured with a Abbott Precision Xtra Blood Glucose and Ketone Monitoring Meter Kit on 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours after consuming the study foods.

arm_group.description: Subjects will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1. Subjects will fast overnight for approximately 19 hours.
Subjects will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1. Subjects will fast overnight for approximately 15 hours and then consume a breakfast bar on day 2.
Subjects will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1. Subjects will fast overnight for approximately 15 hours and then consume a Fast Bar on day 2.

intervention.description: Study subjects will consume a standardized ready-to-eat meal as dinner.
Subjects in all groups will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1 and then fast overnight for approximately 15 hours.
Study subjects will either continue to fast for 6 hours (Fast Group), consume either a breakfast (Breakfast Group) or a Fast Bar (Fast Bar Group).

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Fast Group
group.description: Subjects will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1. Subjects will fast overnight for approximately 19 hours. Dinner: Study subjects will consume a standardized ready-to-eat meal as dinner. Fasting: Subjects in all groups will be asked to consume a standardized ready-to-eat dinner meal before 5 pm on day 1 and then fast overnight for approximately 15 hours.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
